[[Order of the Rising Sun|Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun]] (Japan) |relations= |laterwork= }} [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] '''William Riddell Birdwood, 1st Baron Birdwood''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCB|GCSI|GCMG|GCVO|CIE|DSO}} (13 September 1865 – 17 May 1951) was a [[British Army]] officer. He saw active service in the [[Second Boer War]] on the staff of [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]]. He saw action again in the [[First World War]] as Commander of the [[Australian and New Zealand Army Corps]] during the [[Gallipoli Campaign]] in 1915, leading the landings on the peninsula and then the evacuation later in the year, before becoming Commander-in-Chief of the [[Fifth Army (United Kingdom)|Fifth Army]] on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] during the closing stages of the war. He went on to be General Officer Commanding the [[Northern Command (India)|Northern Army]] in India in 1920 and [[Commander-in-Chief, India]], in 1925. ==Early life== William Riddell Birdwood was born on 13 September 1865 in [[Khadki|Kirkee, India]].{{Cite ODNB|id=31898|title=Birdwood, William Riddell|last=James|first=Robert Rhodes|authorlink=Robert Rhodes James|origyear=2004|year=2009}} His father, [[Herbert Mills Birdwood]], born in Bombay and educated in the UK, had returned to India in 1859 after passing the Indian Civil Service examination.{{Cite ODNB|id=31897|title=Birdwood, Herbert Mills|last=Brown|first=F. H.|last2=Stearn|first2=Roger T.|origyear=2004|year=2012}} In 1861, Herbert Birdwood married Edith Marion Sidonie, the eldest daughter of Surgeon-Major Elijah George Halhed Impey of the Bombay Horse Artillery and postmaster-general of the [[Bombay Presidency]]. They would have five sons and a daughter; William was their second son. At the time of William's birth, his father held positions in the Bombay legislative council, and would go on to become a Bombay high court judge. William Birdwood was educated at [[Clifton College]], [[Bristol]].{{cite web|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/birdwood-william-riddell-baron-birdwood-5240 |title=William Birdwood |publisher= Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate=27 May 2013}} ==Military career== After securing a militia commission in the 4th Battalion [[Royal Scots Fusiliers]] in 1883,Heathcote, p. 43 Birdwood trained at the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst]], from which he was commissioned early, owing to the Russian war scare of 1885, becoming a [[Lieutenant (British Army and Royal Marines)|lieutenant]] in the [[12th Royal Lancers|12th (Prince of Wales's) Royal Lancers]] on 9 May 1885.{{LondonGazette|issue=25468|supp=|startpage=2105|date=8 May 1885|accessdate=27 May 2013}} He joined his regiment in [[India]] and then transferred from the 12th Royal Lancers{{LondonGazette|issue=25688|supp=|startpage=1915|date=1 April 1887|accessdate=27 May 2013}} to the [[Indian Staff Corps|Bengal Staff Corps]] on 20 December 1886.{{LondonGazette|issue=25812|supp=|startpage=2469|date=1 May 1888|accessdate=27 May 2013}} He subsequently transferred to the [[5th King Edward's Own Probyn's Horse|11th Bengal Lancers]] in 1887, seeing action on the [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–1955)|North-West Frontier]] in 1891. He later became [[adjutant]] of the [[Governor General's Bodyguard|Viceroy's Bodyguard]] in 1893. He was promoted to [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] on 9 May 1896{{LondonGazette|issue=26768|supp=|startpage=4632 |date=14 August 1896|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and saw action during the [[Tirah Campaign]] in 1897. Birdwood served in the [[Second Boer War]], initially as brigade-major with a mounted brigade in [[Colony of Natal|Natal]] from 10 January 1900 and then as Deputy-Assistant Adjutant-General on the staff of [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]] from 15 October 1900.{{LondonGazette|issue=27382|supp=|startpage=8563 |date=3 December 1901|accessdate=27 May 2013}} Promoted to brevet major on 20 November 1901{{LondonGazette|issue=27359|supp=|startpage=6325 |date=27 September 1901|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and local [[Lieutenant-Colonel (United Kingdom)|lieutenant-colonel]] in October 1901,{{LondonGazette |issue=27383 |date=6 December 1901 |startpage=8643}}Heathcote, p. 44 he became Military secretary to Lord Kitchener on 5 June 1902,{{LondonGazette|issue=27460|supp=|startpage=4969 |date=1 August 1902|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and followed him on his return to the United Kingdom on board the ''SS Orotava'',{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Army in South Africa – Troops returning home |day_of_week=Thursday |date=26 June 1902 |page_number=10 |issue=36804| }} which arrived in [[Southampton]] on 12 July 1902.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Lord Kitchener′s return |day_of_week=Monday |date=14 July 1902 |page_number=6 |issue=36819| }} He received a [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] promotion to [[Lieutenant-colonel (British Army)|lieutenant-colonel]] in the South African Honours list published on 26 June 1902.{{LondonGazette |issue= 27448 |supp=yes |startpage=4191 |endpage=4194 |date= 26 June 1902 }} When Kitchener went to India as Commander-in-Chief in November 1902, Birdwood joined him there as Assistant Military Secretary. He was promoted to the substantive rank of major on 9 May 1903{{LondonGazette|issue=27578|supp=|startpage=4592 |date=21 July 1903|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and appointed Military Secretary to Lord Kitchener with the rank of full [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|colonel]] on 26 June 1905.{{LondonGazette|issue=27851|supp=yes|startpage=7425 |date=7 November 1905|accessdate=27 May 2013}} Having been appointed an [[Aide-de-Camp]] to [[Edward VII|the King]] on 14 February 1906,{{LondonGazette|issue=27885|supp=|startpage=1054 |date=13 February 1906|accessdate=27 May 2013}} he was given command of the [[Kohat Brigade]] on the North West Frontier in 1908Tucker; Roberts, p.388 and promoted to temporary [[brigadier-general]] on 28 June 1909.{{LondonGazette|issue=28288|supp=|startpage=6874 |date=14 September 1909|accessdate=27 May 2013}} Promoted to the rank of [[Major-General (United Kingdom)|major-general]] on 3 October 1911,{{LondonGazette|issue=28580|supp=|startpage=1066 |date=13 February 1912|accessdate=27 May 2013}} Birdwood became [[Quartermaster-General]] in India and a member of the Viceroy's Legislative Council in 1912 and then Secretary of the Indian Army Department in 1913. ===Gallipoli=== [[File:Anzac Cove.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Anzac Cove looking towards Ari Burnu, 1915]] In November 1914 Birdwood was instructed by Kitchener to form an army [[corps]] from the Australian and New Zealand troops that were training in Egypt. He was promoted to temporary [[Lieutenant-General (United Kingdom)|lieutenant-general]] on 12 December 1914{{LondonGazette|issue=29115|supp=yes|startpage=3099 |date=29 March 1915|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and given command of the [[Australian and New Zealand Army Corps]]. Kitchener instructed General [[Ian Standish Monteith Hamilton|Sir Ian Hamilton]], Commander of the [[Mediterranean Expeditionary Force]], to carry out an operation to capture the [[Gallipoli]] peninsula and placed Birdwood's ANZAC Corps under Hamilton's command. Hamilton ordered Birdwood to carry out a [[landing at Anzac Cove|landing]] on 25 April 1915 north of [[Kabatepe]] at a site now known as [[ANZAC Cove]]. The ANZAC Corps encountered high ridges, narrow gullies, dense scrub and strong [[Turkey|Turkish]] resistance and became pinned down. Major-General [[William Bridges (general)|William Bridges]] and Major-General [[Alexander Godley]], the divisional commanders, were both of the view that the Allied forces, dealing with stiffer-than-expected resistance, should be evacuated ahead of an expected attack by Turkish forces.Bean, 1981, pp. 456–457 Nevertheless, Hamilton ordered them to hold fast.Bean, 1981, pp. 460–461 [[File:W. R. Birdwood.jpg|thumb|right|250px|W. R. Birdwood]] Birdwood took effective command of the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]], i.e. all Australian Forces in May 1915 while still commanding Allied troops on the ground at Gallipoli. He launched a major attack on the Turks in August 1915 (the [[Battle of Sari Bair]]) but still failed to dislodge them from the peninsula. Notwithstanding this he was the only corps commander opposed to abandoning Gallipoli. He was promoted to the permanent rank of lieutenant-general on 28 October 1915{{LondonGazette|issue=29341|supp=yes|startpage=10615 |date=27 October 1915|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and given command of the newly formed [[Dardanelles Army]]: the one outstanding success of the campaign was the evacuation led by Birdwood, which took place in December 1915 and January 1916, when the entire force was withdrawn before any Turkish reaction. ===Western Front=== In February 1916 the Australian and New Zealand contingents, back in Egypt, underwent reorganisation to incorporate the new units and reinforcements that had accumulated during 1915: the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps was replaced by two corps, [[I ANZAC Corps]] and [[II ANZAC Corps]], and Birdwood reverted to the command of II ANZAC Corps. When I ANZAC Corps became the first to depart for France, Birdwood, as senior corps commander, took over command. Birdwood was promoted to the permanent rank of full [[General (United Kingdom)|general]] on 23 October 1917{{LondonGazette|issue=30376|supp=yes|startpage=11661 |date=12 November 1917|accessdate=27 May 2013}} with command of a formation then known as the [[Australian Corps]] in November 1917. He was also appointed [[Aide-de-Camp General]] to [[George V|the King]] on 2 November 1917{{LondonGazette|issue=30365|supp=|startpage=11361 |date=2 November 1917|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and given command of the [[Fifth Army (United Kingdom)|British Fifth Army]] on 31 May 1918 and led the Army at the liberation of [[Lille]] in October 1918 and at the liberation of [[Tournai]] in November 1918. ==After the war== {{CSS image crop |Image = 1920, field marshall lord william birdwood and nawab khan zaman khan, commander in chief india.jpg |bSize = 250 |cWidth = 250 |cHeight = 250 |oTop = 125 |oLeft = 0 |Location = right |Description = Birdwood as Commander-in-Chief of the [[British Indian Army]], together with [[Nawab]] Sir [[Muhammad Khan Zaman Khan]]. At [[Darband, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Darband]], [[Amb (princely state)|Amb State]], 1925 }} Birdwood was made Baronet of Anzac and of Totnes, in the County of Devon on 29 December 1919.{{LondonGazette|issue=31708|supp=|startpage=15988|date=30 December 1919|accessdate=27 May 2013}} He toured Australia to great acclaim in 1920 and then became General Officer Commanding the [[Northern Command (India)|Northern Army]] in India later that year.Heathcote, p. 45 He was promoted to [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|field marshal]] on 20 March 1925,{{LondonGazette|issue=33031|supp=|startpage=1954 |date=20 March 1925|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and, having been appointed a Member of the Executive Council of the [[Governor-General of India]] in July 1925,{{LondonGazette|issue=33069|supp=|startpage=4957 |date=24 July 1925|accessdate=27 May 2013}} he went on to be [[Commander-in-Chief, India]], in August 1925. After leaving the service in 1930, Birdwood made a bid to become [[Governor-General of Australia]]. He had the backing of the [[George V of the United Kingdom|King]] and the British government. However, the Australian [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[James Scullin]] insisted that his Australian nominee [[Isaac Isaacs|Sir Isaac Isaacs]] be appointed. Instead Birdwood was appointed Master of [[Peterhouse, Cambridge]], on 20 April 1931.{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=66643#s11 |title=The colleges and halls – Peterhouse|publisher= British History Online|accessdate=27 May 2013}} In 1935 he wrote for the Western Australian distance education magazine ''[[Our Rural Magazine]]'' claiming that he had two granddaughters making good use of distance courses for educational purposes.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32812573|title=Our rural magazine|date=18 October 1934|publisher=The West Australian (Perth, WA : 1879–1954)|page= 14|accessdate=27 May 2013}} He retired from academic work in 1938. In retirement Birdwood was colonel of the [[12th Royal Lancers]],{{LondonGazette|issue=31889|supp=yes|startpage=5218|date=4 May 1920|accessdate=27 May 2013}} colonel of the [[6th Queen Elizabeth's Own Gurkha Rifles|6th Gurkha Rifles]]{{LondonGazette|issue=33141|supp=|startpage=1834|date=12 March 1926|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and Captain of [[Deal Castle]].{{LondonGazette|issue=34140|supp=|startpage=1631|date=8 March 1935|accessdate=27 May 2013}} In January 1936 he attended the funeral of [[George V|King George V]]{{LondonGazette|issue=34279|supp=yes|startpage=2770|date=29 April 1936|accessdate=27 May 2013}} and in May 1937 he was present for the [[coronation of King George VI]].{{LondonGazette|issue=34453|supp=yes|startpage=7081|date=10 November 1937|accessdate=27 May 2013}} He was raised to the peerage in recognition of his wartime service as '''Baron Birdwood''', of Anzac and of [[Totnes]] in the [[Devon|County of Devon]] on 25 January 1938.{{London Gazette |issue=34477 |date=28 January 1938 |startpage=578 |nolink=yes |accessdate=9 October 2015}}{{LondonGazette|issue=34469|supp=yes|startpage=1|date=1 January 1938|accessdate=27 May 2013}} His autobiography ''Khaki and Gown'' (1941) was followed by ''In my time: recollections and anecdotes'' (1946). Birdwood died at [[Hampton Court Palace]] where he lived in Grace-and-favour apartments on 17 May 1951. He was buried at Twickenham Cemetery with full [[military honours]]. The Australian Government still pays for the upkeep of his grave.{{cite news|last1=Miranda|first1=Charles|title=Brit revered by Diggers|work=Courier-Mail|date=11 April 2015|page=54}} ==Honours and 1921{{LondonGazette|issue=13673|supp=|startpage=138|date=25 January 1921|city=e|accessdate=27 May 2013}} ==Family== In 1893 Birdwood married Janetta Bromhead, daughter of [[Bromhead baronets|Sir Benjamin Bromhead]]; they had a son and two daughters. His wife died in 1947. The son, [[Christopher Birdwood,_2nd_Baron_Birdwood|Christopher Birdwood]] (1899–1962), succeeded him as 2nd Baron Birdwood. The elder daughter was Constance 'Nancy' Birdwood,{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/blog/2011/02/14/for-valentines-day/|title=For Valentine's Day – The airman who married the general's daughter|last=Schmidt|first=Nicholas|publisher=Australian War Memorial|date=14 February 2011|accessdate=4 January 2014}} and the younger daughter was Judith Birdwood. Other members of the Birdwood family include Labour minister and peer [[Christopher Thomson, 1st Baron Thomson|Christopher Birdwood Thomson]] (1875–1930), Anglo-Indian naturalist [[George Christopher Molesworth Birdwood|Sir George Birdwood]] (1832–1917), and [[Jane Birdwood, Baroness Birdwood|Jane Birdwood]] (1913–2000), the second wife of William Birdwood's son.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1345459/The-Dowager-Lady-Birdwood.html|title=The Dowager Lady Birdwood|publisher=The Telegraph|date=29 June 2000|accessdate=4 January 2014}} ==Coat of arms== {{Infobox COA wide |image = [[Image:Arms of Baron Birdwood.svg|100px|Arms of Baron Birdwood]] |image size = |notes = [[Coat of arms]] of the Birdwood family |coronet = A [[coronet]] of a [[Baron]] |crest = Out of a Mural Crown Gules a Martlet Argent between two Branches of Laurel proper |escutcheon = Azure five Martlets two two and one within an Inescutcheon voided a representation of the Southern Cross all Argent |supporters=Dexter: a Sergeant of the XIIth (Prince of Wales's Royal) Lancers mounted on a Bay Horse;
